speaker: Programmer
text: How do I register key events?

speaker: Apiza
text: You'll most likely want to be using al_key_down:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: bool al_key_down(const ALLEGRO_KEYBOARD_STATE *state, int keycode)\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Return true if the key specified was held down in the state specified.

speaker: Programmer
text: Can I use keyboard events as an event source?

speaker: Apiza
text: Yes,

speaker: Apiza
text: you'll want to use something like:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: al_register_event_source(event_queue, al_get_keyboard_event_source());

speaker: Programmer
text: What event type is a keyboard event?

speaker: Apiza
text:
One of the following:

ALLEGRO_EVENT_KEY_DOWN
ALLEGRO_EVENT_KEY_UP
ALLEGRO_EVENT_KEY_CHAR

speaker: Programmer
text: How do I access the keycode from an event object?

speaker: Apiza
text: ev.keyboard.keycode will get you the keycode for event ev.

speaker: Programmer
text: What are the keycodes for up, down, left and right?

speaker: Apiza
text: The keycodes for the arrow keys are the following:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
ALLEGRO_KEY_LEFT
ALLEGRO_KEY_RIGHT
ALLEGRO_KEY_UP
ALLEGRO_KEY_DOWN

speaker: Programmer
text: al_get_keyboard is failing with "Assertion `new_keyboard_driver\' failed".

speaker: Programmer
text: What might be the cause of this?

speaker: Apiza
text: Have you called al_install_keyboard?

speaker: Programmer
text: How do I call al_install_keyboard?

speaker: Apiza
text: al_install_keyboard() should work.\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: bool al_install_keyboard(void)\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Install a keyboard driver.

speaker: Apiza
text: Returns true if successful. If a driver was already installed, nothing happens and true is returned.

speaker: Programmer
text: How do I play a sound in Allegro?

speaker: Apiza
text: You should be able to play a sound with al_play_sample:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
bool al_play_sample(ALLEGRO_SAMPLE *spl, float gain, float pan, float speed,
 ALLEGRO_PLAYMODE loop, ALLEGRO_SAMPLE_ID *ret_id)

speaker: Apiza
text: Plays a sample on one of the sample instances created by al_reserve_samples.

speaker: Apiza
text: Returns true on success, false on failure.

speaker: Apiza
text: Playback may fail because all the reserved sample instances are currently used.\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
Parameters:

gain - relative volume at which the sample is played; 1.0 is normal.
pan - 0.0 is centred, -1.0 is left, 1.0 is right, or ALLEGRO_AUDIO_PAN_NONE.
speed - relative speed at which the sample is played; 1.0 is normal.
loop - ALLEGRO_PLAYMODE_ONCE, ALLEGRO_PLAYMODE_LOOP, or ALLEGRO_PLAYMODE_BIDIR
ret_id - if non-NULL the variable which this points to will be assigned an id representing the sample being played. If al_play_sample returns false, then the contents of ret_id are invalid and must not be used as argument to other functions.

speaker: Programmer
text: How do I load a sample in Allegro?

speaker: Apiza
text: You should be able to load a sample with al_load_sample:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: ALLEGRO_SAMPLE *al_load_sample(const char *filename)\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Loads a few different audio file formats based on their extension.\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Note that this stores the entire file in memory at once, which may be time consuming. To read the file as it is needed, use al_load_audio_stream.\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Returns the sample on success, NULL on failure.

speaker: Programmer
text: How do I get more detailed error information from Allegro?

speaker: Apiza
text: I don't think you can get more detailed information than you're already getting.

speaker: Apiza
text: Is there any error in particular you're having trouble with?

speaker: Programmer
text: al_load_sample is returning NULL.

speaker: Programmer
text: Is there any way to find out why?

speaker: Apiza
text: al_load_sample returns NULL on failure.

speaker: Apiza
text: Have you called al_init_acodec_addon?\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: bool al_init_acodec_addon(void)\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
This function registers all the known audio file type handlers for al_load_sample, al_save_sample, al_load_audio_stream, etc.

Depending on what libraries are available, the full set of recognised extensions is: .wav, .flac, .ogg, .opus, .it, .mod, .s3m, .xm, .voc.

speaker: Apiza
text:
Limitations:

Saving is only supported for wav files.

The wav file loader currently only supports 8/16 bit little endian PCM files. 16 bits are used when saving wav files. Use flac files if more precision is required.

Module files (.it, .mod, .s3m, .xm) are often composed with streaming in mind, and sometimes cannot be easily rendered into a finite length sample. Therefore they cannot be loaded with al_load_sample/al_load_sample_f and must be streamed with al_load_audio_stream or al_load_audio_stream_f.

.voc file streaming is unimplemented.

speaker: Programmer
text: Now al_load_sample is segfaulting.

speaker: Programmer
text: Is there anything else I need to do before calling al_load_sample?

speaker: Apiza
text: You'll also want to call al_reserve_samples:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: bool al_reserve_samples(int reserve_samples)\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
Reserves a number of sample instances, attaching them to the default mixer. If no default mixer is set when this function is called, then it will create one and attach it to the default voice. If no default voice has been set, it, too, will be created.

If you call this function a second time with a smaller number of samples, then the excess internal sample instances will be destroyed causing some sounds to stop and some instances returned by al_lock_sample_id to be invalidated.

This diagram illustrates the structures that are set up:

 sample instance 1
 / sample instance 2
default voice <-- default mixer <--- .
 \ .
 sample instance N

speaker: Apiza
text: Returns true on success, false on error.

speaker: Apiza
text: al_install_audio must have been called first.

speaker: Programmer
text: How do I load a font?

speaker: Apiza
text: al_load_font will allow you to load a font:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: ALLEGRO_FONT *al_load_font(char const *filename, int size, int flags)\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Loads a font from disk. This will use al_load_bitmap_font_flags if you pass the name of a known bitmap format, or else al_load_ttf_font.\n\nThe flags parameter is passed through to either of those functions. Bitmap and TTF fonts are also affected by the current bitmap flags at the time the font is loaded.

speaker: Programmer
text: What flags can be passed to al_load_font?

speaker: Apiza
api_labels: directives purpose quality patterns examples environment

speaker: Programmer
text: How do I display text?

speaker: Apiza
text: al_draw_text should allow you to display text:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
void al_draw_text(const ALLEGRO_FONT *font,
 ALLEGRO_COLOR color, float x, float y, int flags,
 char const *text)

speaker: Apiza
text: Writes the NUL-terminated string text onto the target bitmap at position x, y, using the specified font.\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
The flags parameter can be 0 or one of the following flags:

ALLEGRO_ALIGN_LEFT - Draw the text left-aligned (same as 0).
ALLEGRO_ALIGN_CENTRE - Draw the text centered around the given position.
ALLEGRO_ALIGN_RIGHT - Draw the text right-aligned to the given position.
It can also be combined with this flag:

ALLEGRO_ALIGN_INTEGER - Always draw text aligned to an integer pixel position. This was formerly the default behaviour. Since: 5.0.8, 5.1.4

speaker: Apiza
text: This function does not support newline characters (\\n), but you can use al_draw_multiline_text for multi line text output.

speaker: Programmer
text: al_load_font is returning NULL.

speaker: Programmer
text: What are some possible reasons?

speaker: Apiza
text: Are you sure the filename and size are correct?

speaker: Programmer
text: What is the size parameter in al_load_font?

speaker: Apiza
text: The size parameter determines the size the font will be rendered at, specified in pixels. The standard font size is measured in units per EM, if you instead want to specify the size as the total height of glyphs in pixels, pass it as a negative value.

speaker: Programmer
text: Do I need to call anything before calling al_load_font?

speaker: Apiza
text: You may need to call al_init_font_addon and/or al_init_ttf_addon, along with al_create_display in order to display the font once it has loaded.

speaker: Programmer
text: How do I load an image?

speaker: Apiza
text: You should be able to load an image from a file with al_load_bitmap:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: ALLEGRO_BITMAP *al_load_bitmap(const char *filename)\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
Loads an image file into a new ALLEGRO_BITMAP. The file type is determined by the extension, except if the file has no extension in which case al_identify_bitmap is used instead.

Returns NULL on error.

This is the same as calling al_load_bitmap_flags with a flags parameter of 0.

speaker: Apiza
text: Note: the core Allegro library does not support any image file formats by default. You must use the allegro_image addon, or register your own format handler.

speaker: Programmer
text: Do I need to call anything before calling al_load_bitmap?

speaker: Apiza
text: You'll probably want to call al_init_image_addon:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: bool al_init_image_addon(void)\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
Initializes the image addon. This registers bitmap format handlers for al_load_bitmap, al_load_bitmap_f, al_save_bitmap, al_save_bitmap_f.

The following types are built into the Allegro image addon and guaranteed to be available: BMP, DDS, PCX, TGA. Every platform also supports JPEG and PNG via external dependencies.

Other formats may be available depending on the operating system and installed libraries, but are not guaranteed and should not be assumed to be universally available.

The DDS format is only supported to load from, and only if the DDS file contains textures compressed in the DXT1, DXT3 and DXT5 formats.

speaker: Apiza
text: Note that when loading a DDS file, the created bitmap will always be a video bitmap and will have the pixel format matching the format in the file.

speaker: Programmer
text: I need PNG support,

speaker: Programmer
text: how do I load that?

speaker: Apiza
text: As long as you've called al_init_image_addon you should already have PNG support.

speaker: Apiza
text: Are you having trouble loading a PNG file?

speaker: Programmer
text: I've loaded the bitmap,

speaker: Programmer
text: how do I blit it onto another bitmap?

speaker: Apiza
text: What do you want to do with the two bitmaps?

speaker: Programmer
text: I want to draw one bitmap over another

speaker: Apiza
text: al_draw_bitmap should allow you to draw a second bitmap over the first:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: void al_draw_bitmap(ALLEGRO_BITMAP *bitmap, float dx, float dy, int flags)\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Draws an unscaled, unrotated bitmap at the given position to the current target bitmap (see al_set_target_bitmap).\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
flags can be a combination of:

ALLEGRO_FLIP_HORIZONTAL - flip the bitmap about the y-axis
ALLEGRO_FLIP_VERTICAL - flip the bitmap about the x-axis

speaker: Apiza
text: Note: The current target bitmap must be a different bitmap. Drawing a bitmap to itself (or to a sub-bitmap of itself) or drawing a sub-bitmap to its parent (or another sub-bitmap of its parent) are not currently supported. To copy part of a bitmap into the same bitmap simply use a temporary bitmap instead.\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Note: The backbuffer (or a sub-bitmap thereof) can not be transformed, blended or tinted. If you need to draw the backbuffer draw it to a temporary bitmap first with no active transformation (except translation). Blending and tinting settings/parameters will be ignored. This does not apply when drawing into a memory bitmap.

speaker: Programmer
text: How do I scale a bitmap?

speaker: Apiza
text: al_draw_scaled_bitmap should allow you to scale a bitmap:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
void al_draw_scaled_bitmap(ALLEGRO_BITMAP *bitmap,
 float sx, float sy, float sw, float sh,
 float dx, float dy, float dw, float dh, int flags)

speaker: Apiza
text: Draws a scaled version of the given bitmap to the target bitmap.\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
sx - source x
sy - source y
sw - source width
sh - source height
dx - destination x
dy - destination y
dw - destination width
dh - destination height
flags - same as for al_draw_bitmap

speaker: Apiza
text: See al_draw_bitmap for a note on restrictions on which bitmaps can be drawn where.

speaker: Programmer
text: How do I get a bitmap's width and height?

speaker: Apiza
text: al_get_bitmap_height and al_get_bitmap_width should allow you to do that:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: int al_get_bitmap_height(ALLEGRO_BITMAP *bitmap)\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Returns the height of a bitmap in pixels.\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: int al_get_bitmap_width(ALLEGRO_BITMAP *bitmap)\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Returns the width of a bitmap in pixels.

speaker: Programmer
text: How do I rotate a bitmap?

speaker: Apiza
text: al_draw_rotated_bitmap should let you rotate a bitmap:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
void al_draw_rotated_bitmap(ALLEGRO_BITMAP *bitmap,
 float cx, float cy, float dx, float dy, float angle, int flags)

speaker: Apiza
text:
Draws a rotated version of the given bitmap to the target bitmap. The bitmap is rotated by 'angle' radians clockwise.

The point at cx/cy relative to the upper left corner of the bitmap will be drawn at dx/dy and the bitmap is rotated around this point. If cx,cy is 0,0 the bitmap will rotate around its upper left corner.

speaker: Apiza
text:
cx - center x (relative to the bitmap)
cy - center y (relative to the bitmap)
dx - destination x
dy - destination y
angle - angle by which to rotate (radians)
flags - same as for al_draw_bitmap

speaker: Apiza
Apiza
text: See al_draw_bitmap for a note on restrictions on which bitmaps can be drawn where.

speaker: Programmer
text: How do I capture mouse events?

speaker: Apiza
text: al_get_mouse_event_source will give you the mouse event source:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: ALLEGRO_EVENT_SOURCE *al_get_mouse_event_source(void)\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Retrieve the mouse event source. All mouse events are generated by this event source.\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Returns NULL if the mouse subsystem was not installed.

speaker: Programmer
text: How do I install the mouse subsystem?

speaker: Apiza
text: al_install_mouse should do that:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: bool al_install_mouse(void)\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Install a mouse driver.\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: Returns true if successful. If a driver was already installed, nothing happens and true is returned.

speaker: Programmer
text: What does a mouse click event look like?

speaker: Apiza
text: ALLEGRO_MOUSE_STATE's buttons field will tell you whether or not it has been clicked:\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: typedef struct ALLEGRO_MOUSE_STATE ALLEGRO_MOUSE_STATE;\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
Public fields (read only):

x - mouse x position
y - mouse y position
w, z - mouse wheel position (2D 'ball')
buttons - mouse buttons bitfield

The zeroth bit is set if the primary mouse button is held down, the first bit is set if the secondary mouse button is held down, and so on.

pressure - pressure, ranging from 0.0 to 1.0

speaker: Programmer
text: What is the event type of a mouse click?

speaker: Apiza
text: ALLEGRO_EVENT_MOUSE_BUTTON_DOWN\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text: A mouse button was pressed.\n\n

speaker: Apiza
text:
mouse.x (int)
x-coordinate
mouse.y (int)
y-coordinate
mouse.z (int)
z-coordinate
mouse.w (int)
w-coordinate
mouse.button (unsigned)
The mouse button which was pressed, numbering from 1.
mouse.pressure (float)
Pressure, ranging from 0.0 to 1.0.
mouse.display (ALLEGRO_DISPLAY *)
The display which had mouse focus.
